items.title: Albanese in New York for UN meeting | Midday News Bulletin 21 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese arrives in New York for a meeting of the UN General Assembly, Australia and allies are threatened with "punitive measures" over Palestinian. And in athletics, Australian Mackenzie Little has secured her second bronze medal on the international stage.

items.title: A cyber attack has hit some of Europe's busiest airports. Here's what you need to know
items.summary: The cyber attack on check-in systems caused cancellations and long delays for thousands of passengers.

items.title: Republicans warn Australia of 'punitive measures' recognising Palestinian statehood
items.summary: Anthony Albanese will recognise Palestinian statehood along with other world leaders at the UN General Assembly this week.

items.title: At least 60 Palestinians killed as Israel presses on with Gaza City assault
items.summary: The Israeli military estimates it has demolished up to 20 Gaza City tower blocks over the past two weeks.

items.title: Here's the tea: Global shortage means steep prices for matcha lovers
items.summary: Global matcha prices are surging due to poor weather in Japan, rising global demand, labour shortages, and steep US tariffs on imports from Japan and China. Now, the world’s love affair with matcha may be tested - at the checkout counter.

items.title: White House issues clarification after Trump hits H-1B visas with $150,000 fee
items.summary: The announcement sparked concerns among employees across swaths of corporate America.

items.title: John Santi lays his brother's remains to rest after finding out museum displayed specimens without consent
items.summary: A coronial investigation launched in Tasmania in 2016 has found the University of Tasmania removed and kept human remains without consent or approval. The investigation raises broader questions about collections of human remains in other universities and museums in Australia, and what obligation these institutions have to identify their origin.

items.title: A fourth fatality confirmed in the Optus Triple-Zero outage | Morning News Bulletin 21 September 2025
items.summary: A fourth fatality confirmed as authorities investigate the Optus triple-zero outage; Hamas issues a hostage farewell montage as Israel continues to pound Gaza City; and in sport, reigning premiers Brisbane Lions book their spot in the AFL finals.

items.title: Opinions divided on how to save our precious mountain ash forests
items.summary: New research has found Australia's heat-stressed forests are rapidly thinning, and could even be producing carbon emissions. It comes as the government prepares to release its 2035 emissions targets and a climate risk report later this month. But local researchers, politicians and Traditional Owner land groups remain divided on how to protect the forest.

items.title: The UN has reached a historic milestone. The world will be watching what it does next
items.summary: This week's United Nations meeting will be a landmark occasion for multiple reasons.

items.title: 'Not exactly glamorous': The 'disheartening' reality of dating in rural Australia
items.summary: Rural Australians say dating in the country is a whole lot harder than in the city, with geographic isolation the least of their worries. Finding someone with the same values and lifestyle priorities is often the hardest challenge, which is why singles events in the sticks are having such a big impact.

items.title: A full federal government inquiry into the deadly Optus outage
Federal government inquiry into fatal Optus outage | Evening News Bulletin 20 August 2025
items.summary: A full federal government inquiry into the deadly Optus outage... Estonia says Russia's reported violation of its airspace shows its time to get tough... and a big, late blow for the Canberra Raiders ahead of tonight's huge National Rugby League semi-final

items.title: The 'quite simple' way this group of Australians could save lives
items.summary: Australians receiving treatment for "urgent" and "critical" diseases are having to wait for people overseas to make life-saving donations.

items.title: 'Unprecedentedly brazen': Estonia invokes Nato treaty after Russian jets violate airspace
items.summary: Russia's defence ministry denied its jets violated Estonian airspace, saying they flew over neutral waters.

items.title: SA Premier launches an examination of Optus' conduct | Midday News Bulletin 20 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Peter Malinauskas launches an examination of Optus' conduct after the deaths of two South Australians were linked to the telco's outage; Estonia seeks NATO help after Russian warplanes enter its airspace; and in sport, Canada ends New Zealand's eight-year reign as women's rugby world champions.

items.title: Why some Australian parents are giving their kids as much as $200k
items.summary: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter.

items.title: Jess Hull breaks Australian record and qualifies for 800m final at World Athletics Championships
items.summary: The 28-year-old recorded a time of 1:57.15 and placed third in her semi-final heat in Tokyo on Friday night.

items.title: TikTok deal still unclear as Trump, Xi lower tensions in first call in months
items.summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping have pledged to meet in South Korea next month after their first phone call in three months.

items.title: The 80th General Assembly of the UN is meeting in New York. How does it work - and why?
items.summary: World leaders will gather in New York next week for the annual General Assembly. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has highlighted peace, climate, responsible innovation, gender equality, development financing and UN reform as central themes of the week. But the high-level week of the General Assembly also marks the 80th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. We take a look at just what the UNGA is and what its powers are.

items.title: I feel like privacy is dead: IVF data breach triggers interest in class action lawsuit
items.summary: After years of trying to conceive, Isabel Lewis thought the hard part was over — until cybercriminals targeted her fertility clinic. The data breach at Genea Fertility included patient's medical histories, diagnoses and treatments, medications and prescriptions, as well as pathology and diagnostic test results. Now, hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit over the breach, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

items.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
items.summary: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

items.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
items.summary: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

items.title: Healing land and spirit through Noongar knowledge and regenerative land management
items.summary: In Western Australia's Wheatbelt, a region long shaped by industrial farming practices, a new model of regenerative agriculture is taking root. At Yaraguia farm, Ballardong Noongar man Oral McGuire is healing Country, reconnecting First Nations knowledge of caring for Country with modern land management to restore ecosystems and produce food that benefits both the land and the community.

items.title: Free speech fears continue to roil US as Trump says unfair media coverage is 'illegal'
items.summary: What began as a late-night joke has spiralled into a test of free speech in Trump’s America.

items.title: 'Really angry': Isabel is one of hundreds considering class action against this IVF provider
items.summary: Hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

items.title: Optus’ triple-zero outage is unacceptable, says minister | Morning News Bulletin 20 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Optus's technical outage causing a triple-0 failure is unacceptable, minister says; A British couple detained by the Taliban in Afghanistan for nearly eight months is released; and in AFL, Geelong beats Hawthorn into the Grand Final but loses star defender Tom Stewart to concussion.

items.title: Three people dead after Optus network upgrade sparked triple-zero call failure
items.summary: Two of the deceased were from South Australia and one from Western Australia, Optus CEO Stephen Rue said.

items.title: Israelis shot at Allenby Crossing into Jordan
items.summary: The Israeli military has confirmed four of its personnel were killed in Rafah as well as two Israeli citizens, in a shooting described as a terrorist attack at Allenby Crossing. The crisis has deepened divisions around the world and at the United Nations, where a US veto blocked a resolution calling for a ceasefire and unrestricted aid.

items.title: Age pension to rise & is AI in bubble territory?
items.summary: Stephanie Youssef speaks with Omkar Joshi from Opal Capital Management for the day's sharemarket news, including whether AI is in bubble territory, while SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves goes through the upcoming age pension changes with Joshua Parisotto from HESTA.

items.title: 'Right plan for Australia': Government ministers defend 2035 climate target
items.summary: Climate advocates say the federal government's 2035 emissions reduction target falls "dangerously short", while the Coalition has said its plan is "grounded in fantasy land". Government ministers are now working to justify the target to the public and the community, as the Coalition is under pressure to outline their climate policy.

items.title: Why we're retiring five years later — and the 'big problem' for future generations
items.summary: A "significant shift" has pushed back the age Australians are retiring, according to an author of a new report.

items.title: Coalition raises concerns over climate goal cost | Evening News Bulletin 19 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, the Coalition reveals concerns over the cost of the government's new emissions target, ANU chancellor Julie Bishop defies pressure to resign, defending herself against bullying claims. And in cricket, Australian captain Pat Cummins shares his plan to recover in time for the Ashes.

items.title: What we know about Charlie Kirk's memorial service
items.summary: Charlie Kirk, a right-wing political commentator, was assassinated while speaking at a university campus in the US state of Utah last week.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Telecommunications blackout, power being restored in Gaza | Midday News Bulletin 19 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, a telecommunications blackout as Israel's army advances on Gaza City, Donald Trump reveals he is negotiating to take back a strategic airbase in Afghanistan. And in sport, sprinting prodigy, Gout Gout, promises a comeback after elimination from the World Athletics Championships.

items.title: Why landmark coercive control laws have only led to a handful of charges
items.summary: NSW Police recorded 297 incidents of coercive control in the year since it was criminalised in the state, but laid charges only on nine occasions.

items.title: Trump's new warning to TV networks as criticism over Kimmel suspension mounts
items.summary: The head of the US' broadcasting regulator said the cancellation was part of a "massive shift" taking place in US media and that Jimmy Kimmel's show wouldn't be "the last shoe to drop".

items.title: Trump and Starmer keep it civil despite disagreements
items.summary: Donald Trump says Vladimir Putin has “let him down”, and revealed the US is working to regain control of a key air base in Afghanistan, during a wide-ranging press conference that marked the end of his state visit to the United Kingdom. British Prime Minister Keir Starmer farewelled his guest - relieved the trip went without any major controversy.

items.title: Police arrest seven teenagers over stabbing deaths of Melbourne boys
items.summary: Seven males between the ages of 15 and 19 will be interviewed by Victoria Police detectives in connection with the stabbings earlier this month.

items.title: Sydney's army of Olympic volunteers mark 25 years
items.summary: This week marks 25 years since the opening of the Sydney Olympics. From welcoming athletes to washing t-shirts, an army of than 46,000 volunteers helped maintain the smooth running of the games - including pioneer volunteers who volunteered in the years leading up to the games.

items.title: Two killed in a shooting at the Israel Jordan border | Morning News Bulletin 19 September 2025
items.summary: Two killed in a shooting at the Israel Jordan border; Fears for a pilot after a suspected plane crash on the New South Wales south coast; And in sport, Gout Gout and Torrie Lewis both out of the world titles in Tokyo.

items.title: The Aussie dollar is having a moment. Here's what it means for you
items.summary: The Australian dollar is trading at around a 10-month high against the US dollar and has been broadly performing "very well". But it's not the whole story, experts say.

items.title: Ned's grandson died in police custody. Three months on, the cause still isn't confirmed.
items.summary: The police-led investigation into Kumanjayi White's death in custody is still ongoing, amid growing frustration and anger from the Yuendumu community.

items.title: Gout Gout is out of the World Athletics Championships — but time is on his side
items.summary: The 17-year-old placed fourth in the second semi-final on Thursday night with a time of 20.36 seconds.

items.title: Foreign policy, free speech and Epstein: Takeaways from Trump and Starmer's press conference
items.summary: The US and UK leaders hailed the renewal of the countries' "special relationship" as Trump's state visit drew to a close.

items.title: Trump's royal treatment, UN declares 'genocide' in Gaza & Albania's AI minister
items.summary: Donald Trump gets some face time with the King & Queen on a state visit to the UK. A UN commission of inquiry finds Israel’s war in Gaza amounts to genocide as Israel’s ground operation in Gaza City gets underway. MAGA vows war on the left in response to Charlie Kirk's killing and Bolsonaro is sentenced to 27 years in jail. Plus, Albania unveils an all AI minister.

items.title: The $500 million problem caused by an 'out-of-date' super rule
items.summary: One part of Australia's superannuation system has been "frozen for years" — and its a problem that could be leaving some shortchanged, according to a new report.

items.title: Regulator says Kmart's use of facial recognition technology breached privacy laws
items.summary: Retail giant Kmart has been accused of violating customers' privacy with its use of facial recognition. The company says it trialled the technology to tackle increased theft and fraud and is considering appealing the Privacy Commissioner's ruling.

items.title: Full-time jobs tumble, US cuts rates & future of chocolate prices
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Blair Chapman from Seek about the latest jobs data which showed a near 41,000 fall in full-time jobs; Lochlan Halloway from Morningstar takes a look at the day's sharemarket action including the reaction to the US Federal Reserve's first interst rate cut this year; and Stephanie Youssef discusses the future of chocolate prices with Paul Joules from Rabobank.

items.title: Too high or too low? Australia's 2035 climate target pleases no one
items.summary: As one of the world's biggest greenhouse gas emitters per capita, Australia has announced its new 2035 emissions reduction target. The federal government has committed to a target to cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent by 2035, based on 2005 levels. Some say the target is too high, others say it's too low. Labor says it's both ambitious and achievable.

items.title: 'One of the highest honours of my life': Donald Trump hails UK state visit amid protests
items.summary: United States President Donald Trump is visiting the United Kingdom where he has met with members of the Royal family and talked up the historical bond between the two countries.

items.title: 'Not likely to please anyone': Labor's 'ambitious' new emissions target faces criticism
items.summary: The updated target has been criticised as both insufficient and overly ambitious.

items.title: Mixed reactions to Australia's 2035 emissions target | Evening News Bulletin 18 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, the government hands down its net zero climate target for 2025, veteran broadcaster Alan Jones pleads not guilty to dozens of sexual abuse charges. And in sport, US Olympic sprinter Fred Kerley is the first track athlete to sign on to the Enhanced Games.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 18 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Palestinians fleeing Gaza City as Israel opens additional exit passage
items.summary: Hundreds of thousands of Gazans are fleeing south as Israel’s bombardment of the enclave intensifies, with families forced to carry children and the elderly along designated so-called safe routes.Meanwhile, Israel’s far-right finance minister has controversially described Gaza as a potential real estate bonanza once demolished.

items.title: Palestinians flee Gaza City as bombing continues | Midday News Bulletin 18th September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, numbers of Palestinians flee Gaza City as Israel's bombing continues, unemployment rises slightly, in line with the Reserve Bank's expectations. And in football, Ange Postecoglou cops his second loss in two games as coach of Nottingham Forrest.

items.title: Ben and Jerry's co-founder quits over parent company Unilever 'silencing' activism
items.summary: Jerry Greenfield said the independence of the company to pursue social activism on progressive issues — a key element in its sale to the British multinational in 2000 — was "gone".

items.title: Unlawful: Kmart's facial recognition tech breached Australians' privacy, watchdog finds
items.summary: Kmart broke Australian privacy laws through its use of facial recognition technology, the privacy commissioner has found. The retail giant said it was "disappointed" by the findings and was reviewing appeal options.

items.title: Jimmy Kimmel Live taken off air indefinitely after host's Charlie Kirk comments
items.summary: Kimmel suggested during his show this week that Donald Trump's base had used the death of right-wing commentator Kirk for political gain.

items.title: Calls for change to Low Income Super Tax Offset rule
Albanese unveils 2035 emissions reduction target — and billions in new funding
items.summary: The federal government has unveiled a target to cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent.

items.title: The transnational links between extremist groups fuelling protests in Australia and the UK
items.summary: Experts say there are a number of driving forces behind recent mass demonstrations in Australia and the UK, and says they are "not particularly exceptional". They also say media organisations need to treat this issue with caution when reporting.

items.title: Pomp, protests and an 'eternal' bond on day one of Donald Trump's UK state visit
items.summary: The visit, marked by record security, protests and awkward questions over Jeffrey Epstein, is being used by UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer to push trade talks and secure major US tech investments.

items.title: New exit route opened in Gaza city | Morning News Bulletin 18 September 2025
items.summary: Israel offers 48 hours and a new escape route for civilians in Gaza City; Australia's first Indigenous parliamentarian honoured in Canberra; Running sensation Gout Gout makes the next round at the world championships.

items.title: The key question for Australia after UN report's Gaza genocide finding
items.summary: The UN Independent International Commission of Inquiry report found Israel is committing genocide in Gaza — an accusation it denies. Experts say the recommendations provide a blueprint for the Australian government to take stronger action, but will it?

items.title: I grew up in several blended families. Olivia was the only stable maternal figure in my life
items.summary: Actor and singer Tottie Goldsmith didn’t have much contact with her mother growing up and was raised in blended families as her dad remarried several times. She says that she craved emotional stability and connection during this time and so found a consistent maternal figure in her late aunt, Olivia Newton-John.

items.title: Gout Gout soars into semifinal 'against the big dogs' at World Athletics Championships
items.summary: Sprint sensation Gout Gout has lived up to the hype by qualifying for the 200m semi-finals at the world championships.

items.title: Israel opens 'temporary' new route out of Gaza City for 48 hours as tanks advance
items.summary: An Israeli official said military operations were focused on getting civilians to head south and that fighting would intensify over the next month or two.

items.title: Australia's newest citizens welcomed in ceremonies on Australian Citizenship Day
items.summary: Thousands are celebrating becoming new Australians, as local councils hosted ceremonies around the country for Australian Citizenship Day. SBS spoke to some of the new citizens.

items.title: The bank of mum and dad helping first home buyers, & investors look to US Federal Reserve
items.summary: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter, so SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with UBS Economist Stephen Wu to find out to what extent they're helping. Plus Kyle Rodda from capital.com looks through the day's sharemarket action and previews the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

items.title: Charlie Kirk killing suspect could face death penalty after being formally charged with murder
items.summary: The 22-year-old suspected of killing conservative activist Charlie Kirk has been formally charged with capital murder. Meanwhile, the fallout from the assassination continues to reverberate across the United States, in the courts, in politics, and in public debate.

items.title: No deal: Albanese leaves empty-handed after PNG delays defence pact
items.summary: The Prime Minister is leaving Papua New Guinea empty-handed after a landmark security agreement wasn't signed in the final hours. The delayed deal comes less than two weeks after a similar defence with Vanuatu was delayed over concerns it will affect their other relationships.

items.title: UN commission says Israel committed genocide; thousands flee Israeli assault on Gaza City
items.summary: Israel has intensified its ground assault on Gaza City just hours after a UN committee released a report adding to widespread accusations of genocide. The Australian government is among a growing chorus of countries - and hostage families - calling for Israel to change course.

items.title: Charlie Kirk's alleged killer has been charged. Trump's base has its sights on a different target
items.summary: Fears are growing of a looming crackdown on Donald Trump's perceived political opponents after the US president and members of his administration warned the "radical left" would face consequences for the assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk.

items.title: PM says defence deal with PNG to be signed within weeks | Evening News Bulletin 17 September 2025
items.summary: Anthony Albanese says he is confident a defence pact with Papua New Guinea is weeks away from being signed; Australia's newest citizens welcomed in ceremonies held around the country; and Peter Bol shattered after being edged out in the heats at the World Athletics Championships.

items.title: Four arrested after Epstein, Trump images projected on castle ahead of president's visit
items.summary: Four adults were arrested on suspicion of malicious communications after protesters unfurled a massive banner featuring a photograph of Trump and Epstein near Windsor Castle, and later projected several images of the pair onto one of its towers.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Hollywood pays tribute to Robert Redford after acting legend's death
items.summary: Hollywood actors have reflected on Robert Redford's legacy after the actor died aged 89.

items.title: Australia-PNG defence pact on hold, but PM insists it'll still be inked
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was expected to sign the landmark defence treaty while visiting Papua New Guinea.

items.title: Chalmers reacts to Trump's rebuke as ABC journalist says president was 'feisty'
items.summary: The ABC's Americas editor John Lyons joked he would have to "brace himself" after US President Donald Trump said he was going to tell Prime Minister Anthony Albanese about him.

items.title: 'I had enough of his hatred': Texts reveal motive as charges filed in Charlie Kirk murder
items.summary: Utah prosecutors have charged 22-year-old Tyler Robinson with the murder of right-wing activist Charlie Kirk, announcing plans to seek the death penalty.

items.title: When Andrea’s husband died, their blended family was 'instantaneously decimated'
items.summary: Maintaining contact with step or blended family after a separation can be difficult and give rise to mixed emotions — especially when there are no legal responsibilities between stepparents and stepchildren.

items.title: Modified and dangerous: The popular 'illegal motorbikes' on Australia's roads
items.summary: Modified e-bikes that can run well over their legal speed limit are causing serious injuries and even deaths — is it time for Australia to crack down?

items.title: Cocaine, cartels, and questions: Concerns over Trump's drug boat 'hunt'
items.summary: The US has carried out deadly strikes on Venezuelan boats it alleges carried 'narcoterrorists'. But are these killings lawful? And why is the US turning its focus to the South American nation?

items.title: 'Carnage': Israel launches major ground offensive in Gaza
items.summary: The ground incursion into Gaza City comes as a UN independent commission concluded in a report that Israel has committed genocide in Gaza.

items.title: 'As data-minimising as possible': under-16 social media ban guidelines published
items.summary: Australia's eSafety commissioner has published regulatory guidelines for social media platforms, giving effect to the government's under-16 social media ban. While the ban won't be in place until December 10th, the eSafety commissioner says they want it to be as minimally invasive as possible. Under the guidance, social media platforms will not have to verify the age of every user on their platforms.

items.title: Deep rifts widen further within Coalition under climate change pressure
items.summary: Liberal senator Jonathan Duniam has warned the Coalition will face a "mass exodus" from its frontbench if it adopts a net zero policy without caveats, handing Opposition leader Sussan Ley a fresh test over the party's stance on climate action. The warning comes a day after Liberal MP Andrew Hastie threatened to quit the party if it pursued a policy of net zero emissions by 2050.

items.title: Israel has committed genocide against Palestinians in Gaza, UN inquiry finds
items.summary: The UN commission of inquiry concluded that Israeli authorities and forces had, since October 2023, committed "four of the five genocidal acts" listed in the 1948 Genocide Convention.

items.title: Australian dollar hits a 10 month high against the US
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a look at the driving forces in the currency markets with Chris Weston from Pepperstone and previews the US Federal Reserve's Thursday morning interest rate decision.

items.title: Cash-for-votes, deepfakes and propaganda: Russia's latest bid for influence
items.summary: As Russia's neighbour prepares to head to the polls, a pro-Russian alliance appears to be on the rise thanks, in part, to a disinformation and propaganda campaign some believe is backed by the Kremlin.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 16 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Doctor 'furious' after being told to leave Virgin Australia lounge for expressing breast milk
items.summary: Virgin Australia has apologised, saying the way the matter was handled "fell short" of its standards.

items.title: What social media platforms will — and won't — have to do under Australia's under-16s ban
items.summary: Australia's eSafety commissioner has unveiled guidelines for social media companies to comply with age restriction laws that will come into effect on 10 December. Here's what we know.

items.title: Moldova heads to an election: but will Russian interference change the result?
items.summary: Voters in Moldova head to the polls later this month, in an election authorities warn is being undermined by a campaign of vote buying and digital propaganda, orchestrated by Moscow. Independent investigators believe up to 40% of votes will be the result of the Russian interference campaign, which seeks to promote pro-Kremlin parties and slow Moldova’s plans to join the European Union.

items.title: 'Israel is fighting a war of slavery': Strong criticism from emergency summit in Qatar
items.summary: Arab and Islamic leaders have met in Doha following Israel’s strike that killed Hamas officials and a Qatari security officer. Qatar’s Emir accused Israel of seeking dominance, while Iran, Turkey and Egypt called for sanctions, isolation and regional defence coordination.

items.title: Liberal senator warns of 'mass exodus' from Coalition frontbench over net zero
items.summary: The Liberal party is once again at loggerheads over the party's stance on net zero, with another frontbencher warning against adopting a policy "at any cost".

items.title: Gout Gout is through to his World Athletics Championships semi-final. Here's how to watch
items.summary: The Australian sprinting sensation is making his senior international debut in Tokyo. Here's what you need to know.

items.title: Kurtis Marschall takes pole vault bronze for Australia at World Athletics Championships 2025
items.summary: Pole vaulter Kurtis Marschall has won Australia's first medal of the Tokyo world championships and Mondo Duplantis has broken his own world record in the event.

items.title: Israel threatens Hamas 'wherever they are' as Arab leaders review ties after Qatar attack
items.summary: Arab and Muslim leaders called for a review of ties with Israel after emergency talks in Doha following last week's strike in the Qatari capital.

items.title: US, China reach 'framework' deal on TikTok ownership ahead of Trump's call with Xi
items.summary: The United States and China have reached a framework agreement to shift TikTok to US-controlled ownership, with final confirmation expected in a call between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping.

items.title: Inside the 'hyper-connected' nationalist groups fuelling protests in Australia and the UK
items.summary: There is a complex picture behind the recent mobilisation of the far-right across Australia and the UK. But experts say it's happened before.

items.title: How much money do you really need to be happy? Here's what the research says
items.summary: Recent data shows that economic inequality in Australia is increasing.

items.title: Rubio says US will provide 'unwavering support' for Israel in Gaza war
items.summary: Benjamin Netanyahu said Marco Rubio's visit was a "clear message" the United States stood with Israel.

items.title: Experts warn rates double for some sexually transmitted infections
items.summary: The latest snapshot of sexually transmitted infections in Australia shows some alarming trends over the past 10 years. A report from the University of New South Wales' Kirby Institute suggests testing gaps and accessibility issues are contributing to a rise in cases.

items.title: ANZ cops $240m fine for widespread misconduct
items.summary: The Australian share market has begun the week lower, despite optimism ahead of the US Federal Reserve’s expected interest rate cut this week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Macquarie Private Bank Division Director Martin Lakos. Plus, ANZ has been fined $240 million for what ASIC has called widespread misconduct, including allegations of failing to respond to customer hardship notices and failing to refund fees charged to thousands of dead customers. For more, Asha Abdi spoke with Professor Allan Fels from the University of Melbourne.

items.title: 'No Australian spared': National Climate Risk Assessment delivers dire warning
items.summary: Coastal hazards driven by climate change could put three million people at risk by 2090 if Australia warms by 3 degrees, according to a major body of new climate research released by the federal government. The National Climate Risk Assessment has been released, as the government prepares the ground to announce its carbon emissions reduction target for 2035.

items.title: Adolescence star Owen Cooper becomes youngest male actor to win an Emmy
items.summary: The four-part series he starred in recorded 140 million views in its first three months on Netflix, and drew rave reviews.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 15th September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Urgent calls for the federal government to adopt recommendations to combat Islamophobia
items.summary: Prominent calls are being made for the federal government to adopt newly-introduced recommendations, following a report by the government-appointed Envoy to Combat Islamophobia. It follows data from the Islamophobia Register Australia, revealing a 530 per cent increase in incidents since October 7, 2023.

items.title: Arab leaders urge international community to stop applying 'double standards' to Israel
items.summary: An Israeli strike on Doha last week has set off a wave of condemnation, with Arab and Islamic leaders gathering in Qatar to arrive at a united response. Israel, meanwhile, is standing firm, deepening its alliance with Washington as the war in Gaza rages on.

items.title: No Australians immune: What 2050 and beyond will look like for your city
items.summary: Australia is likely to experience more intense and extreme climate hazards — in some cases where people and places haven't experienced them before.

items.title: 'Does my head in': Albanese closes electorate office, blaming pro-Palestinian protesters
items.summary: Announcing the closure, the prime minister cited protesters who have "repeatedly blocked access" to the electorate office over the past two years.

items.title: 'A real slap in the face': ANZ to be handed record fine for misconduct
items.summary: The penalties the financial watchdog and ANZ will request include a record $80 million fine for unconscionable conduct.

items.title: Iranian women find new ways to resist three years on from Mahsa Amini's death
items.summary: In Iran, mandatory hijab laws sparked nationwide protests three years ago over death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini. While the presence of morality police on the streets has declined, the regime says it is instead using digital tools such as citizen-watch apps, drones and facial recognition to enforce its crackdown. But women are finding new ways to resist.

items.title: Suspect in Charlie Kirk shooting 'not cooperating' with investigators, Utah governor says
items.summary: Police investigating Tyler Robinson, the Utah man suspected of shooting right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk, have yet to establish a motive for the killing. Utah's governor said he would be formally charged on Tuesday.

items.title: Albanese says Australia-PNG defence treaty on par with US and New Zealand
items.summary: More detail will be provided once the defence agreement is signed on Wednesday, the prime minister said.

items.title: Albanese says Australia-PNG defence treaty on par with US and New Zealand
items.summary: More detail will be provided once the defence agreement is signed on Wednesday, the prime minister said.

items.title: Qatari prime minister says 'time has come to punish Israel' after unprecedented strike on Doha
items.summary: Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani has called on the world to reject what he called "double standards" after an Israeli strike on Doha, as Arab and Islamic leaders attend an emergency summit.

items.title: Cali lives a proud 'trad life'. But a former tradwife says the lifestyle left her 'dead inside'
items.summary: 'Tradwife' influencers like Cali believe a woman’s most important roles are as a wife and a mother — and they also believe in sharing that lifestyle to their online followers. But a former tradwife says the growing popularity of this content is extremely concerning.

items.title: Rubio reiterates unwavering US support for Israel as dozens killed in Gaza City offensive
items.summary: The US secretary of state said Israel's recent airstrike in Qatar was "not going to change the nature of our relationship with the Israelis" but the two nations were "going to have to talk about" its impact on Gaza ceasefire negotiations.

items.title: This common bathroom habit could be doing you more damage than you think
items.summary: Using your phone on the throne could lead to an increased risk of haemorrhoids, according to a new study, but some experts say it's not the full story.

items.title: Government to spend $12 billion on 'world-class' AUKUS defence facility in WA
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a $12 billion investment into a Western Australian defence precinct, which is set to bolster Australia's ability to build warships and host nuclear-powered submarines.

items.title: Torrie Lewis breaks her own Australian 100m record at World Athletics Championships 2025
items.summary: Sprint queen Torrie Lewis has given Australia a flying start to the world athletics championships with a record-breaking 100m run.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Is there life on Mars? New research seems to show there was, once.
items.summary: This week, NASA announced findings of potential biosignatures on Mars. Does that mean there's proof that there was once life on Mars? In this edition of Weekend One on One, Dr Micheal Tice, geology professor at Texas A&M University, who's involved in the ongoing research project, explains what the findings mean.

items.title: INTERVIEW: The new Aged Care Act and the 'unintended consequences' preventing transformational change
items.summary: A new Aged Care Act is weeks away from coming into effect, but there are aspects that has the Inspector-General of Aged Care concerned.

items.title: Loo scrolling: Study investigates link between this bathroom habit and a painful health condition
items.summary: Using your phone while on the toilet could be linked to an increased chance of haemorrhoids, according to a study from the United States. So if you're a loo scroller, the extra time spent on the toilet could be doing you more harm than good.

items.title: What next for the Coalition after its 'entirely unedifying week'?
items.summary: Liberal senator Jane Hume says the Coalition is looking to "move on" after demoting colleague Jacinta Nampijinpa Price over controversial comments about Indian immigration. But what are the lessons the Coalition should draw from the episode?

items.title: 'I'm ready to be arrested': How women in Iran fight 'state-sanctioned sexual violence'
items.summary: Three years after the death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini, which sparked the widespread "Woman, Life, Freedom" movement, women are still finding ways to protest against the regime's new methods of crackdown.

items.title: Nick was a 'subservient' child in church, but 'tiny little cracks' eventually shattered his faith
items.summary: It took an "unravelling" for musician Nick Carpenter to be able to reckon with his religious upbringing in America's south and find his voice in songwriting. But he still thinks about the person he could have been.

items.title: Concerns over political extremism after rival rallies held across Australia
items.summary: Politicians are warning against the risks of extremism and political violence, after rival rallies were held in Australia's capital cities and regional centres.

items.title: Protesters clash in Melbourne as rival rallies unfold across the country
items.summary: Opposing protests took place across all capital cities and some regional areas on Saturday and, as police had predicted, things got most heated in Melbourne

items.title: Nepal announces interim leader, sets election date after week of violent protests
items.summary: Sushila Karki has become Nepal's first woman prime minister, following two days of intense negotiations between the president, army chief and protest leaders behind the country's worst upheaval in years, which left at least 51 people dead.

items.title: Police in Australia raise concerns ahead of protests | Afternoon Bulletin 13 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Police are concerned about chaos, as left and right wing protests begin; Social media platforms urged to take down videos of the Charlie Kirk shooting; and in sport; Officials found to have placed hundreds of bets on races in Tasmania.

items.title: Neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell given community work order for intimidating police officer
items.summary: Thomas Sewell was found guilty of intimidating a police officer over threats to "dox" him and his wife.

items.title: 'Paradigm shift': Over 2 million homes to get internet speed boost starting this weekend
items.summary: The free speed boost is one of the biggest changes to Australian internet in history, according to one expert.

items.title: PM's wardrobe malfunction and SUV diplomacy: What you missed from the Pacific summit
items.summary: Australia's fossil fuel exports remain a source of tension as Pacific leaders double down on their support for a bid to co-host global climate talks.

items.title: 'More political in recent years': Fresh details emerge about suspected Charlie Kirk shooter
items.summary: Tyler Robinson expressed dislike for Charlie Kirk in the lead-up to the conservative commentator's assassination, investigators have been told.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Supermarket sweep: How making wise choices could save you money
items.summary: Making the switch from branded products to a store's home brand alternatives could save shoppers thousands of dollars each year at checkout, according to a financial comparison website. SBS's Cameron Carr has been finding out more from Compare the Market spokesman Phillip Portman.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Three years after the death of Mahsa Amini in Iran, what's changed?
items.summary: Dr Dara Conduit at the University of Melbourne explains the impact of the death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini three years ago on women's rights in Iran today.

items.title: Bruce McAvaney on Australia's emerging athletics 'golden age' and the run that inspired us all
items.summary: Australia's "golden age" in athletics is gathering steam, esteemed sports commentator Bruce McAvaney says, as the World Athletics Championships gets underway.

items.title: $548.5 million: The price the government is willing to pay 'to avoid a public trial' of robodebt
items.summary: The robodebt class action settlement has been billed as the largest of its kind in Australian history. However, one expert argues it represents "accountability avoided", leaving questions of misfeasance unanswered.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Envoy Aftab Malik on 'going to the roots' of Islamophobia in Australia
items.summary: The Special Envoy to Combat Islamophobia has handed down his long-awaited report, containing 54 recommendations to the federal government.

items.title: Former Virgin CEO’s $50m payday; & is a US rate cut locked in?
items.summary: Former Virgin Australia CEO Jayne Hrdlicka is collecting a $49.9 million pay packet, which includes 10 million shares, as revealed in the company’s annual report. For more on this and the ASX-200’s performance this week, Stephanie Youssef spoke with IG Markets analyst Tony Sycamore. Plus, US inflation has risen 2.9% in August, paving the way for the first US interest rate cut of the year when the Federal Reserve meets next week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with AMP Chief Economist Shane Oliver.

items.title: Why the final approval for North West Shelf gas plant has Indigenous groups and environmentalists worried
items.summary: The federal government has given the final approval for the Woodside North West Shelf gas project with a series of conditions. The approval comes ahead of the Albanese government's announcement of a 2035 emissions reduction target, and after Australia emphasised its commitment to tackling climate change to Pacific leaders.

items.title: A 5-minute guide to the World Athletics Championships – and how to watch from Australia
items.summary: Australia has kicked off one of its biggest track and field campaigns in history, with a record number of athletes in Tokyo to contest the 2025 World Athletics Championships.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 12 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Brazil's former President Bolsonaro sentenced to jail
items.summary: Brazil's former President, Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to prison after being convicted of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 election. Mr Bolsonaro, who has denied any wrongdoing, has not attended the court and has only sent his lawyers.He is the first former president in the country's history to be convicted for attacking democracy.

items.title: Ireland says it will boycott Eurovision 2026 if Israel is allowed to participate
items.summary: Irish broadcaster RTE said it would be "unconscionable" to take part in the contest alongside Israel, given its ongoing assault on Gaza.

items.title: 'Doesn't cut the mustard': Indian Australian community leaders demand Price apology
items.summary: While welcoming an apology from Opposition leader Sussan Ley, one Indian Australian community figure said "the Liberal Party has their work cut out to repair the damage" caused by senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's comments on Indian immigration.

items.title: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in jail for plotting coup
items.summary: The firebrand ex-president was convicted of plotting a coup after his 2022 election loss, and accused of acting "with the purpose of eroding democracy and institutions".

items.title: More than a million Australians could be living with dementia in 40 years. These are possible risk factors
items.summary: A new report has also found dementia was Australia's leading cause of death in 2023.

items.title: 'People starting to act out': How the Charlie Kirk shooting suggests a 'vicious spiral' in the US
items.summary: Is the US seeing a rise in political violence, and could it spread to Australia?

items.title: Julie Bishop hits back at bullying claims and vows to stay at ANU after deputy quits
items.summary: ANU chancellor Julie Bishop has rejected bullying allegations, and has vowed to serve out her term after vice-chancellor Genevieve Bell quit following months of controversy.

items.title: Sydney sets 146-year rainfall record as severe weather eases
items.summary: Over the 24 hours to 9am on Thursday, Sydney received a total of 122mm of rain, marking its heaviest daily rainfall for September since 1879.

items.title: US stocks benefit from Oracle surge; home ownership dream slipping
items.summary: The ASX 200 has closed 0.3% lower with healthcare stocks dragging the index down, despite gains by gold miners. That’s almost despite Oracle’s shares soaring almost 40% in its best one-day performance since 1992, lifting the S&P 500 and other global markets to record highs. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets. Plus, new analysis from Domain shows the dream of owning a home is becoming further out of reach – with deposit hurdles, coupled with climbing house prices and mortgage repayments, driving the sharpest generational divide in decades. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Domain’s research chief, Dr Nicola Powell.

items.title: What you might not know about tornadoes in Australia
items.summary: There are about 60-80 tornadoes each year in Australia, according to a meteorologist. But you're unlikely to see them.

items.title: Israel strikes Qatar, why it's been a bad week to be a PM & the real 'Succession' finale
items.summary: Israel's strike on Qatar blows up ceasefire talks, the prime ministers of Nepal, Japan and France depart in a hurry, and Albanese battles for influence in the Pacific, while Moldova battles to stop Putin’s influence ahead of elections. Plus, the Murdoch succession is finally settled.

items.title: 'I won't be silenced': Jacinta Price axed from Coalition frontbench in fallout over Indian migration remarks
items.summary: Northern Territory Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has been removed from the Coalition frontbench, following fallout from remarks she made about Indian migrants. Sydney Lang takes a look at how the last week unfolded.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 11 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Europe on high alert after Russian drones shot down over Poland
items.summary: Poland has reported its most serious airspace breach since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, after nearly 20 drones entered from Belarus and Ukraine. European leaders have condemned Moscow for reckless escalation, with the Kremlin saying such accusations are baseless.

items.title: Ley apologises to Indian Australians, says Price remains 'valued' party member after sacking
items.summary: Sussan Ley's apology come after she dumped Jacinta Nampijinpa Price from the Opposition frontbench over the senator's remarks about Indian migrants and her refusal to endorse her leadership.

items.title: Bali floods leave at least 19 people dead and five missing
items.summary: Floodwaters rose to over 2.5 metres in some areas, with more than 800 people forced into temporary shelters.

items.title: 'Girt by sea' explained: National anthem now in 60+ languages
items.summary: Ever wondered what "girt by sea" means, especially if your first language isn't English? SBS Audio has brought Australia’s national anthem to life in more than 60 languages, so everyone can understand the words behind the music.

items.title: Qatar says 'regional response under way' after Israeli strike on Doha
items.summary: Gulf leaders have rallied in solidarity with Qatar as global condemnation over the strikes grows.

items.title: Trump 'filled with grief' over Charlie Kirk's shooting. Here's what to know about the right-wing activist

items.title: 'Incredibly rare': The million-dollar question on Dezi Freeman's arrest reward
items.summary: There's $1 million available for anyone who can help facilitate the arrest of accused double murderer Dezi Freeman. But do financial incentives actually help solve crimes?

items.title: How much you need for a comfortable retirement? | NAB latest to cut jobs
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about the day's market action including why banks seem to be on a job cutting cycle, plus Stephnie Youssef speaks with ASFA CEO Mary Delahunty to find out how much money is needed in super to fund a comfortable retirement.

items.title: Climate Change and China's Charm: Australia's pressing role to play in the Pacific
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is in the Solomon Islands for the region's most important annual political meeting. With climate change and regional security at the forefront of discussions, Australia will work to solidify its role as a reliable partner and counter to China's growing security presence in the Pacific.

items.title: Breakthrough chlamydia vaccine offers hope for endangered koalas
items.summary: A world-first vaccine for chlamydia in koala populations developed over more than a decade may help the fight against the disease.

items.title: Israel's strike in Qatar a 'devastating blow' to Gaza ceasefire negotiations, experts say
items.summary: Israel has carried out airstrikes and other military action in Lebanon, Syria, Iran and Yemen in the course of the Gaza conflict, but experts say its latest attack on Qatar marks a significant departure and "upsets" efforts for peace.

items.title: 'Absolutely reckless': NATO condemns Russia's violation of Polish airspace
items.summary: Poland invoked NATO's Article 4 for urgent talks after Russian drones violated the country's airspace.

items.title: Upcoming far-right and far-left protests on a violent collision course, police warn
items.summary: People are sick of protesters using rallies as a "veiled excuse to punch on", a Victorian Police spokesperson has said, warning of a rival protests planned for Melbourne this Saturday.

items.title: Will Israel's attack on Hamas officials in Qatar derail peace talks?
items.summary: Israel has struck the Qatari capital of Doha, killing five Hamas members and one Qatari security official. It has led to an outcry from Qatar, Washington, and humanitarian groups, with concern the strike will jeopardise fragile ceasefire talks.

items.title: 'The wrong thing to do': Australia, and the world, react to Israel’s strike on Hamas in Qatar
items.summary: Qatar has once again been caught in the crossfire of Middle East turmoil, with world leaders condemning the attacks amid concerns they deal a serious blow to ceasefire efforts.

items.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
items.summary: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

items.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
items.summary: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

items.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
items.summary: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

items.title: Qatar condemns Israeli attacks on Hamas leaders as 'cowardly' violation of international law
items.summary: Israel's airstrike on Hamas leaders in Qatar killed five, including a commander's son, prompting Qatari condemnation and US unease over ceasefire efforts.

items.title: The simple shopping swap that could save you $4,000 a year
items.summary: A comparison group examined the cost of 20 staple items at two major supermarkets. Here's what it found.

items.title: Palestinians flee Gaza City as Israel airdrops leaflets ordering them to leave
items.summary: Israel has warned it will launch a full-scale assault on Gaza City.

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
items.summary: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
items.summary: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

items.title: ANZ slashes 3,500 jobs, are there more to come?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a closer look at ANZ's decision to cut 3,500 employees and 1,000 contractors and what it means for the sector with Nathan Zaia from Morningstar and Damien Boey from Wilson Asset Management.

items.title: Banksy mural at Royal Courts of Justice swiftly covered after appearing overnight
items.summary: The new Banksy mural appeared to be a commentary on the arrest of hundreds of demonstrators in London for their support of proscribed terrorist organisation Palestine Action.

items.title: Australia Post to lift US shipping pause — but some customers still face a wait
items.summary: Australia Post says a new arrangement will allow it to soon resume postal services to the US for business customers. But for others, there's still uncertainty.

items.title: Donald Trump fails to overturn $126m sex assault defamation verdict
items.summary: A US appeals court upheld an expensive verdict against Donald Trump for defaming writer E Jean Carroll.

items.title: Logging halted to create a koala retreat
items.summary: Australia will halt logging in a large stretch of woodland on the east coast to create a retreat for koalas, in an attempt to save the local population from extinction. The announcement, which will impact six timber mills and hundreds of workers, has caused outrage in the forestry industry. New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says the decision wasn't taken lightly and those affected will be supported.

items.title: The new regional hotspot that's seen a 1,500 per cent surge of city folk
items.summary: More city dwellers are packing their bags and heading for this regional border location, according to the latest Regional Movers Index.

items.title: Weak US data spurs rate cut chance, and the supermarkets court case
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Raymond Chan from Morgans about the day's sharemarket action including the weak US jobs data, a rebalancing of the market's main indexes and the potential implications of a supermarkets underpayments court case.

items.title: Fed up with flight delays? Passengers could soon get refunds under new scheme
items.summary: The federal government aims to implement a new consumer protection scheme for travellers, which could lead to refunds and the establishment of a new complaints-handling body to address flight disruptions.

items.title: K-pop is a global phenomenon. Some of its biggest stars are from Australia
items.summary: From BLACKPINK's Rosé to Stray Kids' Bang Chan and Felix, Australia is slowly making its presence in Korean pop music felt.

items.title: 'Not serious about ceasefire': What Russia's major attack means for the war in Ukraine
items.summary: The strike on Kyiv is less about causing damage, but more a signal from Russian President Vladimir Putin towards the West, an expert says.

items.title: Woolworths and Coles say underpayment court decision could cost them $1 billion
items.summary: The supermarket giants were found not to have complied with their obligations to keep accurate employment records and paid workers' salaries without tracking other entitlements.
